head.title: To Right the Wrongs of Slavery

hedline.hl1: To Right the Wrongs of Slavery

abstract.p: Laurel E Federbush letter replies to Glenn C Loury's May 29 Op-Ed article arguing against payment of reparations to the descendants of slaves

block.p: In ''It's Futile to Put a Price on Slavery'' (Op-Ed, May 29), Glenn C. Loury suggests that the descendants of slaves should not be paid reparations since no amount of money can erase past wrongs.
In ''It's Futile to Put a Price on Slavery'' (Op-Ed, May 29), Glenn C. Loury suggests that the descendants of slaves should not be paid reparations since no amount of money can erase past wrongs.

That's not the point. Slavery itself was an institution that put a price on human lives. Some people and their descendants became wealthy because of the misery and unpaid labor of others, under a system that was largely sanctioned by the United States government. Industries like cotton and tobacco owe much of their prosperity to people held in bondage.

Mr. Loury argues that ''the severity of slavery's 'injury' is far more profound than any cash transfer will be able to reverse.'' Money never truly remedies an injury, but the beneficiaries of slavery are still profiting from it.
LAUREL E. FEDERBUSH Ann Arbor, Mich., May 29, 2000
